Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Synergistic application of cheminformatics and computational geometry approaches for predicting protein-protein interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to develop and deliver, ultimately in the form of user-friendly software, novel approaches to analyzing protein-protein interactions (PPIs) that employ a unique combination of concepts at the interface of structural bioinformatics, computational geometry, and cheminformatics. Protein-protein interactions play a central role in all major signaling events that occur in living cells. A new family of cheminformatics descriptors of PPIs derived from Delaunay tessellation of PPI interface termed SNAP3 (Simplicial Neighborhood Analysis of Protein-Protein Packing), based on the previously-developed SNAPP approach, will be developed. These descriptors will be employed as part of novel approaches to (1) identify hot spot regions on protein surfaces and (2) predict the structure of protein-protein (or protein-peptide) complexes using novel GridDock docking method to be developed in this project.

In the post-genomic era, analysis and prediction of PPIs is considered critical for elucidating of many if not most protein functions to better our understanding of cell biology, cellular networks and human diseases. This project will provide both the experimental and computational communities with novel and powerful methodologies and software for analyzing and predicting PPIs and enable several important applications including: (1) unique description and comparison of PPIs using chemometric approaches; (2) the identification of unknown PPI hot spots on protein surfaces; and (3) rational design of novel peptides with desired binding specificity against target proteins. It will have a broad impact by making all PPI datasets, computational tools, and models developed accessible via a new module within the publicly available framework, the ChemBench web portal.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are crucial for cellular signaling and have been implicated in the numerous diseases, such as cancer. PPIs, thus, are emerging target for drug discovery. The challenge, however, is how to identify the binding site, or interface, on the protein surface where the two proteins will interact. Furthermore, predictions of such interfaces are also needed in the absence of protein complex crystal structures, which can be technically and financially difficult to obtain. Without knowledge of where two proteins will physically interact, drug discovery efforts remain limited. Using approaches developed in the Tropsha lab, which combine structural bioinformatics, computational biology, and cheminformatics, we have identified several key combinations of residues that more most frequently at the interface of PPIs. We have then developed software called Critical Residue Analysis and Complementarity Likelihood (CRACLe) that can find these residues combinations and map them on the protein surface, which will provide researchers insight into the design of small molecules that can disrupt these interfaces. This prediction of potential PPI binding sites using CRACLe can be done on a single protein. Our method represents a significant advance in the field of PPI prediction, as most existing methods require structurally data of both protein partners. Additionally, PPIs can be modulated by small molecules either by inhibiting the interaction or by stabilizing the complex. We have mapped the ligandable sites of PPIs, otherwise known as small molecular binding site, and profiled the surface topology. We found that other key combinations of residues occur more frequently at these ligandable sites than elsewhere on the protein surface. We have also observed that specific combinations of residues at the ligandable site can distinguish and differentiate inhibition sites from stabilization sites. We have incorporated this empirically-derived observation into our CRACLe method, which will now allow us to not only predict protein-protein interfaces, but also ligandable sites for inhibitors and stabilizers.


Last Modified: 01/30/2017
Modified by: Alexander Tropsha

Without knowledge of where two proteins will physically interact, drug discovery efforts remain limited. Using approaches developed in the Tropsha lab, which combine structural bioinformatics, computational biology, and cheminformatics, we have identified several key combinations of residues that more most frequently at the interface of PPIs. We have then developed software called Critical Residue Analysis and Complementarity Likelihood (CRACLe) that can find these residues combinations and map them on the protein surface, which will provide researchers insight into the design of small molecules that can disrupt these interfaces. This prediction of potential PPI binding sites using CRACLe can be done on a single protein. Our method represents a significant advance in the field of PPI prediction, as most existing methods require structurally data of both protein partners. Additionally, PPIs can be modulated by small molecules either by inhibiting the interaction or by stabilizing the complex.
